titlepage.titleproper: A Guide to the Records of the Policy Office: Subject Files of Governor Lawrence Douglas Wilder, 1983-1994 (bulk 1990-1993)
titlepage.subtitle:
A Collection in
the Library of Virginia 35539

did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.unittitle: Records of the Policy Office: Subject Files of Governor Lawrence Douglas Wilder, 1983-1994 (bulk 1990-1994)

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Privacy protected and confidential information is restricted from public access for 75 years per Code of Virginia 42.1-78, 2.2-3800, and 2.2-3705.1-8. Types of previous restricted information may include, but are not limited to: privacy protected information and attorney-client privileged material.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Records of the Policy Office: Subject Files of Governor Lawrence Douglas Wilder, 1983-1994 (bulk 1990-1993). Accession 35539. State government records collection, The Library of Virginia, Richmond, Virginia.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Transferred by Governor Lawrence Douglas Wilder on October 31, 1996.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Original folder titles have been retained.

bioghist.head: Biographical Information
bioghist.p: Lawrence Douglas Wilder was born in Richmond, Va., on January 17, 1931. He graduated from Virginia Union University in 1951 and afterwards was drafted into the Army, where he served in the Korean War from 1952-1953 and received a bronze star. He then attended the Howard University School of Law and graduated in 1959. Douglas Wilder was elected to the Virginia Senate in 1969 as the first African American member since Reconstruction and served in the Senate for five terms. In 1985, he was elected to the office of Lieutenant Governor as the first African American to be elected to statewide office in Virginia. L. Douglas Wilder won the election for Governor of Virginia in 1989 and served from January 13, 1990 to January 14, 1994. He was the first African American to be elected as Governor in United States.

The Policy Office is a division of the Office of the Governor in the Executive Branch of Virginia state Government. During the Wilder Administration, the Policy Office was headed by Walter McFarlane, Executive Assistant for Policy, and four Special Assistants: Richard Taylor (Health and Human Resources, and Education), Robert Blue (Finance and Natural Resources), Jeff Nuechterlein (Economic Development and Transportation), and Lynne Porfiri (Administration and Public Safety). The Policy Office was responsible for review and coordination of all policy matters, including: review of proposed legislation from agencies and Cabinet; formulation of the Governor's legislative initiatives; tracking legislation and serving as legislative liaison; review of General Assembly approved legislation submitted to the Governor for signature, amendment or veto; review of death penalty clemency requests, as well as other pardon and restoration of rights requests; review of legal settlements and other legal matters from the Office of the Attorney General's Office; review of proposed regulations; review of all matters pertaining to the judiciary and writs of habeas corpus; review of proposed executive orders; assistance with speech writing; serving as staff for Governor's special commissions; administrative support for Governor's Fellows program; serving as special interest liaison; acting as in-house counsel; and all correspondence with policy implications or pertaining to sensitive or controversial issues requiring legal overview.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Records of the Policy Office: Subject Files, 1983-1994, during the administration of Governor Lawrence Douglas Wilder. The collection is housed in 48 boxes and includes agendas, briefings, brochures, clippings, contracts, correspondence, financial statements, itineraries, maps, memorandum, newsletters, notes, photographs, programs, publications, reports, and other documents. The collection is arranged alphabetically by folder title.

A number of records relate to the unsuccessful effort by Jack Kent Cooke, then owner of the Washington Redskins football team, to push for the construction of a new football stadium in the Potomac Yard area of Alexandria. The area in question had been a railyard owned by the Richmond, Fredericksburg and Potomac Railroad (RF&P) before it was decommissioned in 1989, opening the site to potential development. The records for the potential stadium deal include surveys, plans, zoning ordinances, and reports. The deal was scrapped in October 1992, and the Washington football stadium was instead built in Prince George's County, MD.

Other topics include the expansion efforts of Virginia Commonwealth University in the Oregon Hill neighbordhood of Richmond; the state drug and alcohol policy, including a number of studies and reports; issues related to the legislative redistricting process that followed the 1990 census, including the creation of an 11th congressional district; the creation and efforts of the 21st Century Commission on African American Males, a national effort to focus national attention on issues facing black males and develop a set of public-policy recommendations and strategies for action; the institution of Project Streamline, an effort to consolidate and simplify management and work processes in state government, improving productivity and effeciency; the Gulf War and potential energy shortages; the National Air and Space Museum; and sole source procurements and contracts.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged alphabetically by folder title.
